purpose: Extract / further discussion of the technical-discuss mailing list
text: <@U0NLZCF8V|juanblanco> set the channel purpose: Extract / further discussion of the technical-discuss mailing list

Message: 1
Date: Tue, 16 Feb 2016 21:59:57 -0500
From: Ira Higgins <irapaulhiggins@gmail.com>
To: <mailto:hyperledger-technical-discuss@lists.hyperledger.org|hyperledger-technical-discuss@lists.hyperledger.org>
Subject: Re: [technical-discuss] hyperledger-live blockchain use
case(s)
Message-ID:
<CABz9ESEeuQ-pj5VurPuLmPxZ5D_o4Y4Oz2tSXhBUOU1uoHEkfg@mail.gmail.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="utf-8"

Has anyone tried the GetGems app yet? They have taken blockchain tech
mainstream with their value-sharing app. I think you will see more and more
people taking this tech live. I do like Ripple in that they have gone live
with their tech as well. Maidsafe is going live with a test version of
their tech which is different than eth, or ripple. Radium has an easy to
use interface for non-code savy people who want to take a stake in the
network. Keep an eye on these projects and others.

Hi all, I won't be able to make it to tomorrow's TSC call as I'm on site with a client...for agenda item regarding CI Options I'd like to recommend Go-CD (<https://www.go.cd/>) if we plan on building many multiple projects and pipelines. I've been a part of teams with robust Go-CD pipelines and it's a really great tool for pipeline orchestration of more complex workflows

text: External communication vote - which I believe is in line with the proposed architecture : While REST has very compelling use cases, I believe that instead of having REST Endpoints, Hyperledger should go with a Client Library/gRPC based framework for external communication.  Full-duplex streaming with gRPC over HTTP/2 is tailored for API use vs typical HTTP status codes, latency and complexity of url and body parsing.
I thought Rest was the protocol for API use? and don't they both i.e. RPC & rest endpoints, have to deal with http status codes and some form of parsing at some point?

text: be sure to build your own base image, as we haven’t uploaded a hyperledger project-specific base image, yet
to do that, go into the baseimage directory and run 'make install'
then, cd to the parent directory and run the 'USE_LOCAL_BASEIMAGE=true vagrant up’ command to get the environment started, you then ssh in and then you can start playing, running tests etc
see <https://github.com/hyperledger-incubator/obc-peer> README.md for how to run tests, etc

Hi all,

find below a presentation I held this week at the San Diego Linux IoT summit on using Blockchains for connecting disparate protocols in a transaction system. It introduces a concept called 'Proof of Understanding', intended to (partially) replace proof of work for creating immutability and allowing different machines and applications with different languages and protocols to interact.

Basic technical idea is: we use a blockchain as a supervised training set to predict future message formats based on previous transactions message formats. For new Connections sender & receiver have to run through an agreement and negotiation process (format, content, action handshake) to agree on how they communicate. The Miner (called here Translator) is responsible for suggesting message formats and upon success gets rewarded in a cryptocurrency. Successful and un-successful handshakes together with relevant features allowing predictions based on Machine Learning algorithms get recorded in the Blockchain.  

Partially replacing 'proof of work' with 'proof of understanding' (calling the resulting System Babelchain after Hitchhiker's babelfish) will allow a smarter and maybe lesser use of Machine energy consumption and via connecting before hands unconnected systems has the potential to disrupt some quasi monopolistic information silos.

This idea is in a white paper status and would need to be prototyped. I'd be interested in hearing people's PoV on the suggestion.

whitepaper (consider this leading)
<https://github.com/Benudek/babelchain/blob/master/Proof%20of%20Understanding%20%E2%80%93%20Babelchain%20Machine%20Communication%20.pdf>

presentation held at Linux IoT summit partially outdated, whitepaper leading)
<https://github.com/Benudek/babelchain/blob/master/IoT%20Babelchain%20-%20A%20Blockchain%20Solution%20to%20the%20'Baskets%20of%20Remotes'%20Problem%20FINAL.pdf>


regards

text: there are standards for expressing contracts and legal documents in XML - it would be interesting to explore how they might be leveraged to convey a contract (that can be printed and is legally accepted) that could reference executable chaincode
<@U0KM61BCP> I've been looking at something similar but used JSON-LD signatures. Interesting schema though.

json-ld is a lightweight syntax to serialize Linked
Data in JSON which is W3C recommendation. A little different with the legalxml, but IMO json-ld can be used to describe the metadata of digital assets in ledger at least. We can adopt both of them to build the link between human readable contracts/assets and digital things in hyperledger.

an isomorphic translation of the OASIS schema to json would also do the trick and would likely be something that could garner the same level of legal acceptance. Since the OASIS spec was developed by lawyers (well, mostly) I would hazard that they have also been working on gaining acceptance for the standard in various jurisdictions.

Appreciate if someone in this channel can answer my question. How to find chaincodeID deployed to the network ?   I'm aware "obc-peer chaincode deploy (with code location)" will return the chaincodeID.name value. However, I have not memoried it unfortunately. How can I find the chaincodeID.name value ?

<@U0KM61BCP> Oasis is good stuff, but top down approach. Requires that everybody agrees to the Standard before it can really be used. Meanwhile CommonAccord can be used today. You can take any doc and “codify” it so that it can be used. It can comply with Oasis standard but does not have to if your needs are outside of what is available
We will discuss these issues with all who are working on this topic at the end of May <http://www.commonaccord.org/index.php?action=doc&file=S/About/Conference/Flyer/0.md>
<@U0N1ST4MN>: the OASIS standard is nearly a decade in the field as a standard.

I was trolling through the fabric issues list and here are some relatively low-hanging problems to be solved. Members all over, have always been available on slack or via the issues to assist. So don’t hesitate to ask for help/guidance/further explanation, and don’t stop here, this is just a quick kick starter list of what should be fairly easy items to tackle. Please jump out there on any of these issues, or others, and thank you for any/all help you can provide! Will add more soon...
issue 562 - Sample app issuing REST calls to run chaincode
issue 662 - Capture stacktrace on error
issue 724 - Remove existing containers for chaincode if not already connected.
let me add a comment to the issue asking if this can be closed
Will try to work on 662 after I finish my business travel in this week

I'm trying to understand something regarding history of world state:

Let's assume I have a chaincode that modifies the state - adds keys, modifies values, removes keys. Is there any way to explore what was the state at a given block height (e.g. 10 blocks below the current tip of the chain)?

<@U0MSG4RL7> - In short, complete history of the state is not maintained. Only ‘latest’ (i.e., the state matching the current block height is maintained) 
However, a series of 'state deltas’ are maintained for last few blocks (configurable - default: 500) - [one state delta corresponds to each block].
These stateDeltas can be used to move the state backward (or forward).  However, this is not exposed as an end user functionality and primarily used in state transfer from a peer.
The other alternative is only to replay the transactions from beginning (which is suitable only for audit kind of scenario)

<@U0Z541B3P>: So building something like a bank account where I want to keep both the current balance and the history of transactions - I would need to put *both* of them into the world state. So keep two keys "<account_id>:balance" (numeric value) and "<account_id>:transactions" (value - array of records) for every account.
<@U0MSG4RL7>: Ideally, the transactions should be fetched from blocks. Should not be need to maintaining explicitly.
<@U0Z541B3P>: I see. And when a peer join it replicates all the blocks history? Also - is there a standard way to keep an index of the blocks (say I want all the transactions to/from account X)?
<@U0MSG4RL7>: there is also table functionality as well

<@U0MSG4RL7>: Yes, when a peer joins - it replicates all the blocks and latest state. I guess <@U0XPR4NP4> can confirm this. 
On indexes, In short - as of now tx are indexed only on uuid. 
But as you mentioned txs should be indexed on address/attributes as well (perhaps, only on NVP - because, NVP are supposed to be used for read queries). There is a related issue open for index by address (<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues/490>). 
In addition, a related feature is ‘events’ mechanism. When a new block is constructed an even is emitted (with the block) which a client can listen to an create desired indexes.

text: <@U0Z541B3P>: Thank you, that's very helpful. I'll look into the Events mechanism.
<@U0MSG4RL7>: currently only validating peers perform the sync.  It is not yet in non validators
<@U0UKTPMG8>: But NVP *do* need the latest state to answer the queries (read-only).
as long as they are chaincode queries
but block level queries would fail
as they attempt to access the non validating peers ledger
chaincode queries are actually TXs, as are Deploy and onvoke
they are forwarded from the non validating peer to the validating peer
oooops, or they will be as soon as I PR the code I am working on :simple_smile:
so , very soon chaincode queries will do this :simple_smile:
so REST calls to /chain would fail
but REST calls to /chaincode/... will be forwarded as TXs
<@U0UKTPMG8>: Ha! OK, I was under the assumtion that "Query" chaincode questions don't modify the chain and therefore can be answered directly by NVP. I probably misread.
it is an issue of privacy
the state is only accessible from VPs
you are correct, they do NOT modify, but require access to data that may be private
<@U0UKTPMG8>: OK I see. So what kind of traffic *is* handled by NVPs? (that is, what do they "save").
or it will when I finish sync :simple_smile:
for now,  (when I push this PR), you will be able to do TXs through nvp (which will be forwarded)
but can also validate by quering VPs

this is the behave test I am adding..


  Scenario Outline: chaincode example02 with 4 peers,1 membersrvc, and 1 non-validating peer.

      Given we compose "<ComposeFile>"
      And I wait "5" seconds
      And I register with CA supplying username "binhn" and secret "7avZQLwcUe9q" on peers:
         | nvp0  |
      And I use the following credentials for querying peers:
         | peer |   username  |    secret    |
         | vp0  |  test_user0 | MS9qrN8hFjlE |
         | vp1  |  test_user1 | jGlNl6ImkuDo |
         | vp2  |  test_user2 | zMflqOKezFiA |
         | vp3  |  test_user3 | vWdLCE00vJy0 |

#      Current issue as blocks NOT synced yet.
#      When requesting "/chain" from "nvp0"
#      Then I should get a JSON response with "height" = "1"


      # Deploy
      When I deploy chaincode "<http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02>" with ctor "init" to "nvp0"
                    | arg1 |  arg2 | arg3 | arg4 |
                    |  a   |  100  |  b   |  200 |
      Then I should have received a chaincode name
      Then I wait up to "<WaitTime>" seconds for transaction to be committed to peers:
                 | vp0  | vp1 | vp2 |
as you can see, you can deploy (TX) through the nvp, and then verify through the VPs
eventually (When sync is done, you will be able to verify through NVP), as current verification is that the TXID is on the block(Which will have been synced)

here is the issue that will allow the TX level forwarding. <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues/1182>

attachments.title: IBM Blockchain
attachments.text: GitHub is where people build software. More than 14 million people use GitHub to discover, fork, and contribute to over 35 million projects.

text: <@U0NLZCF8V> - BMX is currently running commit level d5d1c8576b714a7a7ab4f3b5dbacbe4619d209e2 of the fabric.   For local development, we also provide a signed Docker image at this revision as well built directly from Hyperledger fabric repo - <https://hub.docker.com/r/ibmblockchain/fabric/>   (this is simply for convenience as you can of course just checkout the revision above and build your own image)

<https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain> is just a repo where we post demos / samples which include both chaincode and an associated web app.  We also include functionality to deploy them directly to BMX if you want, but you can of course run the web apps locally and point them to the chaincode running on your own fabric deployment.  As mentioned above, this code is tested against commit level d5d1c8576b714a7a7ab4f3b5dbacbe4619d209e2
and just for full disclosure, I clearly work for IBM and actually own the Bluemix offering
<@U0NLZCF8V>: as <@U0PB67X4K> says, yes indeed and IBM fully intend to stay on this path.

As to the IBM-Blockchain org, some of that possibly should be contributed, but some of those samples are Bluemix specific and wouldn’t necessarily be platform independent - something that hyperledger sample code should strive towards.
and for the record, it isn’t abundantly clear that <@U0PB67X4K> actually works for anyone but himself :wink: j/k
Of course bluemix will have those cloud extras like interoperability with internal services. As long as they are kept in sync with stable releases.

<@U0NLZCF8V>:  yep - that's our plan.  we intend to keep up with the latest stable release in the Bluemix service and the related Docker images.  We actually update the Hyperledger code in our development environment whenever there is a commit to make sure things are working plus of course it is free extra testing for the fabric

<!channel>: Hi everyone, I wanted to share items which the IBM team is focused on over the next week and half. At a high level, Documents for application and Fabric developers Client SDK work, Chaincode access control using tcert attributes, whitelisted members, and stabilizing PBFT consensus and performance. I am publicly broadcasting these items out to open any discussion on these, as well as offer up and encourage anyone interested in jumping in or talking to any of the folks please do so. All feedback is very welcomed. The best way to see specific items is to use this link: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+milestone%3A%22Sprint+5%22>

text: would welcome any assistance in getting that done

Looking at this with community member <@U11MANG9G> ... the desired output is Python / Sphinx / .rst source -- whereas GitHub is straight .md + HTML. We have gotten our .mds to .rst using pandoc (notice would require continuous builds). ... As a backup plan, GitHub's "Beautiful Docs" is the GitHub output. We can always use volunteers who want to be involved ...

Back from MIT Media Lab conference on “Digital contracts, identities and blockchain” and the CommonAccord layer was confirmed to be a key element on top of/next to chaincode to provide the ability to map people, organizations their relationships and describe the real world so that it can be automated through chaincode. I invite you to check <http://www.commonaccord.org|www.commonaccord.org>.

2)  If you are planning to attend, please set up an account at <https://www.zephyrproject.org/doc/contribute/gerrit_accounts.html> (ignore the fact that this is for the Zephyr Project, the process is the same, and it has been documented well here).  You will need to log in to <http://gerrit.hyperledger.org|gerrit.hyperledger.org>.  Once you have signed up, please send your account name to <mailto:rjones@linuxfoundation.org|rjones@linuxfoundation.org>.

3)  Lastly, please send your code review workflow questions to Ry Jones <mailto:rjones@linuxfoundation.org|rjones@linuxfoundation.org> in advance.

If you would like to be directly added to the meeting invite, please send a note to <mailto:tbenzies@linuxfoundation.org|tbenzies@linuxfoundation.org> to be added.
<@U0J038AJK>: I am new to the forum, what's the purpose of the Geritt session

<@U1A9JNB1T> we’ll be transitioning to use of Gerrit soon, so we’re holding a training session (to be recorded) that devs can take in real-time or via the recording to come up to speed on use of the tool.

The Virtual Hackathon will kick-off tomorrow at 10:00am ET.  Dan Middleton has graciously agreed to help kick off the discussion tomorrow morning.  We have a straw-man agenda here (<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ROq44KpxuelkOp8GpceFNcv8K6XfWdaOnknzBk73OMc/edit>) that lists the various call-in details, some proposed topics, etc.  We expect participation from the Community in identifying interesting topics to work on and identifying leaders to drive forward various efforts.  Much like the other Hackathons, this will be run in unconference format.  Please feel free to add comments and suggestions to the Google doc referenced above.
This is really great <@U0J038AJK>. Thanks for the heads-up!
for the fabric, <@U0TFEHX8E> has been tagging issues <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22help+wanted%22>

attachments.title: DAO hack sparks crypto-currency panic
attachments.text: The DAO, a virtual currency fund that relies on the ethereum blockchain, has suffered a sustained attack that has seen $50 million of Ether siphoned off, causing the price of the crypto-currency to plummet.
attachments.fallback: Finextra Research: DAO hack sparks crypto-currency panic

text:
Hyperledger Project Technical Community,

As discussed in the last few weeks of TSC meetings, we will be opening the nomination phase for the TSC steady state election on August 11th as defined in the Charter and agreed upon by the TSC.

As such, we have compiled the following list of all contributors that are eligible to nominate themselves for election.  While we have done everything in our power to ensure its accuracy, we ask you to take one final look before EOD tomorrow (August 10th).
If you are not on this list and should be, please reach out directly to me (if you can reference a specific pull request, that would be helpful).
There are about 10 people highlighted in blue at the bottom of the list (missing either a name or an email), if you have this information, please send me an email.
If your name is highlighted in yellow, we have multiple email addresses for you.  Please confirm with me your preferred email address to be used in conjunction with the election.
We will send a separate email on August 11th to call for nominations from those on the list referenced above, as well as detail out the entire nomination and election process.

Regards,

If you are in interested in participating in a 1-2 hour session of the Whitepaper WG during the virtual Hackfest next week, please indicate your preferred timing at <http://doodle.com/poll/qw94asz6qk6d7z8t>

As a reminder, we will be hosting our first European Hackfest (October 3-4) in Amsterdam (this is the Monday following Sibos).  If you are planning to attend, please register at your earliest convenience.  <https://www.regonline.com/hyperledgerhackfestoctober2016>

In addition, we'll be co-sponsoring a large Hackathon at ABN-AMRO's offices nearby over that weekend (October 1-2).  <https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hyperledger-hackathon-tickets-26798489002>

attachments.text: This ​event ​is ​for ​the ​technical ​community ​working ​on ​or ​interested ​in ​the ​Hyperledger ​Project. ​The ​event ​is ​not ​open ​to ​press ​or ​analysts. ​It ​will ​be ​hosted ​at ​ABN ​AMRO ​

attachments.title: Hyperledger Hackathon
attachments.text: Dear hackers and blockchain lovers, ABN AMRO, together with IBM, Holland FinTech and Linux Foundation are happy to announce the first Hyperledger Hackathon on the 1st-2nd of October in Amsterdam. All developers, hackers, tech students, local and international blockchain community and FinTech companies are welcome to join us to the first 36 hours gathering, focused on the Hyperledger technology.An amazing opportunity to showcase your skills, learn from like-minded mentors and experts and most of all have fun while making awesome stuff.Are you in? If so, be sure to pre-book your ticket.You can register both asHacker: Team of max 6 people or as a single individual (we will assign you a team later on or fill up your group with the missing team member)Visitor: come and have a look around on what these brightful minds are working on Awesome prices for the winning teams: 110k worth of  Bluemix license credits topped up with cool gadgets in the spirit of Virtual Reality Headsets, mini 3d Printers, and drones.More information about the full agenda and details about the different challenges will come closer to the event. Looking forward to meet you in October!

Hi <@U294C6FDW>, I am reposting your great question here for the benefit of the community. You asked I have a question if there are restrictions on the size of table and the entries in the rows and columns. I'm planning to create a table of customers that requires them to put their  reports  that can be 1G  or more in size.  My response would be that 1G is very large. I don’t think anything this size has been tested yet. My suggestion would be to get a hash of the report, and use the hash, while storing the report somewhere else. <@U11HTMW0H> <@U1KFCPFQA> would you agree?
<@U294C6FDW> <@U0W7D64LC> I would agree, it is not the intent to store very large objects in the ledger, rather they can be stored externally, hashed, and store the hash in the ledger
Hi guys, I am rather new to HyperLedger (currently developing on Ethereum). But I am struggling to set-up a HyperLedger environment on my localhost.

Any recommendations for resources w.r.t. getting started? I am current following this: <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/starter/fabric-starter-kit/> but im a bit stuck, need a bit more guidance

Hi <@U2JUCCTBL>, if you would like to get up and running quickly you can choose to use a boilerplate project like <https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/fabric-boilerplate> or  <https://github.com/timblankers/hyperledger-hackathon>. Both have a docker-compose file for your hyperledger network and a nodejs application with the client sdk.

attachments.text: fabric-boilerplate - Get up and running quickly with your own blockchain application!

attachments.title: timblankers/hyperledger-hackathon
attachments.text: hyperledger-hackathon - Boilerplate to quickly start a web app based on Hyperledger Fabric

<@U2JUCCTBL|pdulong> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/pdulong/F2K15SJM9/1__node.png|1__node.png> and commented: Not sure if this is the right channel, but I am struggling to get the boilerplate started. I think my PATH variables might be incorrect? Any suggestions?

initial_comment.comment: Not sure if this is the right channel, but I am struggling to get the boilerplate started. I think my PATH variables might be incorrect? Any suggestions?

text: Make sure your $GOPATH environment variable is set and points to the right directory. Also, I think you need to have $GOPATH/bin in your $PATH
